TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . He is currently residing in GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , when the applicant was living in GPE , a district court in GPE convicted him of being a member of the NORP religious organisation PERSON , prohibited in GPE . The court ordered him to pay a fine in an amount equal to CARDINAL times the minimum DATE wage .

CARDINAL . The applicant paid the fine and continued to reside in GPE . However , according to him , he felt constant pressure from the lawenforcement agencies , which required him to report on all his actions and movements and , in case of delay or failure on his part , threatened to arrest his elder son . So as not to put his family in danger , on DATE the applicant left GPE for GPE .
CARDINAL . In the meantime ORG of GPE quashed the decision of DATE on the ground that the sentence was too mild and remitted the case for fresh examination .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Sobir Rakhimovskiy District Court of GPE ordered the applicant to be remanded in custody . On that basis a cross - border search warrant for the applicant was issued .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in GPE on the basis of the cross - border search warrant .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ORG of the Interior sent ORG of the Interior of GPE a request to keep the applicant in custody and enclosed a copy of ORG decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON Prosecutor 's Office in GPE issued a decision on application of a preventive measure and ordered that the applicant be placed in custody on the basis of the NORP court 's decision of DATE . LAW was cited as a legal source for application of the preventive measure . The decision indicated that the applicant should remain in custody until ORG decided on his extradition ; the term of the detention was not specified . CARDINAL . On DATE ORG requested ORG to extradite the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant that no final decision had been taken in respect of the extradition and there were therefore no grounds to change the preventive measure applied in his case .

CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON Prosecutor 's Office issued a new decision to remand the applicant in custody pursuant to LAW ORG and LAW . The decision indicated that the applicant should remain in custody until ORG decided on his extradition ; the term of the detention was not specified . The applicant was not notified of it until DATE , in the remand prison , as confirmed by his signature on a copy of the decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the request of ORG for the applicant 's extradition because the acts with which the applicant had been charged did not constitute a crime under NORP law .
CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON Prosecutor 's Office received notification from ORG that the NORP authorities ' request for the applicant 's extradition had been dismissed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON Prosecutor 's Office issued a decision authorising the applicant 's release . The applicant was released from the remand prison .

CARDINAL . Everyone has a right to liberty and security ( LAW ) . Arrest , placement in custody and custodial detention are permissible only on the basis of a court order . The term during which a person may be detained prior to obtaining such an order can not exceed TIME ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The term “ court ” is defined by LAW CCP ) of DATE as “ any court of general jurisdiction which examines a criminal case on the merits and delivers decisions provided for by LAW ” ( LAW ) . The term “ judge ” is defined by the ORG as “ an official empowered to administer justice ” ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . A district court has the power to examine all criminal cases except for those falling within the respective jurisdictions of a justice of the peace , a regional court or ORG ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . LAW ORG governs the application of preventive measures . Placement in custody is a preventive measure applied on the basis of a court decision to a person suspected of or charged with a crime punishable with DATE imprisonment where it is impossible to apply a more lenient preventive measure ( LAW ) . A request for placement in custody should be examined by a judge of a district court or a military court of a corresponding level ( LAW ) . A judge 's decision on placement in custody may be challenged before an appeal court within DATE ( LAW ) . The period of detention pending investigation of a crime can not exceed DATE ( LAW ) but may be extended DATE by a judge of a district court or a military court of a corresponding level ( LAW ) . Further extensions may be granted only if the person is charged with serious or particularly serious criminal offences ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . LAW ORG lays down the procedure by which acts or decisions of a court or public official involved in criminal proceedings may be challenged . Acts or omissions of a police officer in charge of the inquiry , an investigator , a prosecutor or a court may be challenged by “ parties to criminal proceedings ” or by “ other persons in so far as the acts and decisions [ in question ] touch upon those persons ' interests ” ( LAW ) . Those acts or omissions may be challenged before a prosecutor ( LAW ) . Decisions taken by police or prosecution investigators or prosecutors not to initiate criminal proceedings , or to discontinue them , or any other decision or inaction capable of impinging upon the rights of “ parties to criminal proceedings ” or of “ hindering an individual 's access to court ” may be subject to judicial review ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . Extradition may be denied if the act that gave grounds for the extradition request does not constitute a crime under LAW ( LAW ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition accompanied by an arrest warrant issued by a foreign judicial body , a prosecutor may place the person whose extradition is being sought under house arrest or in custodial detention without prior approval of his or her decision by a court of GPE ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . When performing actions requested under LAW , a requested official body applies its country 's domestic laws ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition the requested country should immediately take measures to search for and arrest the person whose extradition is sought , except in cases where no extradition is possible ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The person whose extradition is sought may be arrested before receipt of a request for extradition , if there is a related petition . The petition must contain a reference to a detention order and indicate that a request for extradition will follow ( LAW ) . If the person is arrested or placed in detention before receipt of the extradition request , the requesting country must be informed immediately ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Verifying the compatibility of LAW ORG with LAW , ORG reiterated its constant caselaw that excessive or arbitrary detention , unlimited in time and without appropriate review , was incompatible with LAW in all cases , including extradition proceedings .

CARDINAL . In ORG view , the guarantees of the right to liberty and personal integrity set out in DATE and LAW , as well as the legal norms of LAW of the ORG on preventive measures , were fully applicable to detention with a view to extradition . Accordingly , LAW ORG did not allow the authorities to apply a custodial measure without respecting the procedure established in the ORG , or in excess of the time - limits fixed therein .

CARDINAL . The Prosecutor General asked ORG for an official clarification of its decision no . CARDINAL-O of DATE ( see above ) , for the purpose , in particular , of elucidating the procedure for extending a person 's detention with a view to extradition .

CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the request on the ground that it was not competent to indicate specific criminal - law provisions governing the procedure and time - limits for holding a person in custody with a view to extradition . That was a matter for the courts of general jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . In this decision ORG reiterated that LAW ORG did not imply that detention of a person on the basis of an extradition request did not have to comply with the terms and time - limits provided for in the legislation on criminal procedure .
